report_title: Frederick County Public Schools Administrative Efficiency Audit

executive_summary.key_finding: Frederick County Public Schools demonstrates the BEST administrative staffing efficiency among all peer districts. The district has the lowest ratio of administrators to students and the lowest percentage of administrative staff.
summary_points: FCPS has 1.73 administrators per 1,000 students - the LOWEST among all peers (peer avg: 3.97)
Only 1.26% of FCPS staff are administrators - the LOWEST among all peers (peer avg: 3.13%)
Per-pupil spending is $15,734, which is 10.8% BELOW the Virginia state average of $17,636
Enrollment grew 2.8% over 4 years while admin positions grew only 4.8% (within acceptable range)
One area of concern: Admin SPENDING ratio at 10.4% of expenditures (FY2022 NCES) slightly exceeds 10% threshold
executive_summary.conclusion: Based on staffing data, FCPS is NOT over-administered. The district runs a lean administrative operation compared to peers. However, per-position administrative costs should be monitored.

finding_1.title: Administrative Staffing Efficiency - EXCELLENT
finding_1.metric: Admin Staff as % of Total Staff
finding_1.analysis: Frederick County has the lowest administrative staffing ratio of any peer district. With only 24.36 admin positions for 14,121 students, FCPS maintains a remarkably lean administrative structure.

finding_2.title: Students per Administrator - EXCELLENT
finding_2.analysis: FCPS has the highest students-per-admin ratio, meaning each administrator serves more students than any peer district. This indicates efficient administrative resource allocation.

finding_3.title: Per-Pupil Spending - BELOW STATE AVERAGE
finding_3.analysis: FCPS spends 10.8% less per student than the Virginia state average. This indicates fiscal conservatism but also suggests the district may be under-resourced compared to state norms. Local funding ($7,383/pupil) is below the state average ($8,403/pupil).

finding_4.title: Administrative Spending Ratio - BORDERLINE
finding_4.metric: Admin Expenditures as % of Total Current Expenditures
finding_4.analysis: While FCPS has the fewest admin POSITIONS, admin SPENDING as a percentage of total expenditures is slightly elevated at 10.4%. This suggests that per-position admin costs (salary, benefits) may be higher than average. This metric should be monitored.
finding_4.context: This data is from FY2022 NCES. More recent detailed expenditure breakdowns are not yet available. The discrepancy between excellent staffing ratios and borderline spending ratios suggests high per-position compensation.

finding_5.title: Enrollment vs. Admin Growth - ACCEPTABLE
finding_5.threshold: Admin growth should not exceed 2x enrollment growth
finding_5.analysis: Admin position growth has outpaced enrollment growth by 1.7x over 4 years. This is within the acceptable range (<2x). The growth is minimal in absolute terms: from 23.24 to 24.36 positions (only 1.12 additional positions).

finding_6.title: County Budget Share - DECLINING
finding_6.metric: School Funds as % of Total County Budget
finding_6.analysis: The school system's share of the total county budget has declined from 60.8% in FY2020 to 57.0% in FY2025. While county transfers to schools have increased in absolute dollars ($106.7M to $133.5M), other county spending has grown faster.
finding_6.note: This is a county budget allocation issue, not a school administration issue.

finding_7.title: Instruction Spending Ratio - GOOD
finding_7.analysis: FCPS directs 76.1% of spending to instruction, which is above the peer average and well above the 65% target. This is a strong indicator that resources are prioritized for classroom activities.
finding_7.note: FY2024 VPAP data uses a broader 'instruction' category than NCES.

warning_flags.explanation: Slightly exceeds 10% threshold. Driven by per-position costs, not headcount.
warning_flags.recommendation: Review admin compensation benchmarks and consider if positions can be consolidated.

warning_flags.flag: Declining school share of county budget
warning_flags.explanation: Schools' share declined from 60.8% to 57.0% of county budget.
warning_flags.recommendation: This is a county policy decision, not a school efficiency issue. Advocate for maintained funding levels.

favorable_indicators: Lowest admin-to-student ratio among peers (1.73 per 1,000)

recommendations.recommendation: Conduct a salary benchmarking study to understand why admin SPENDING is borderline despite excellent admin STAFFING ratios. This may reveal opportunities for cost optimization without reducing positions.
Present this audit data to the Board of Supervisors to demonstrate efficient school operations and advocate for maintained or increased funding share.
Monitor admin position growth vs. enrollment. Current trajectory is acceptable but should not accelerate.

methodology_notes: Admin staffing ratios calculated from VDOE Table 18 administrative positions divided by total staff and enrollment.
Per-pupil spending from VDOE Table 15 includes local, state, federal, and sales tax funding sources.
Admin spending percentage (10.4%) is from FY2022 NCES data, the most recent available with detailed expenditure breakdown.
VPAP FY2024 data uses a simplified 'instruction vs. other' categorization that does not break out admin separately.
Peer average calculations exclude Frederick County to provide an external benchmark.
limitations: NCES detailed expenditure data is 2 years delayed (FY2022 most recent).
VDOE FY2025 expenditure data not yet released; enrollment data is current.
Warren County FY2024 VPAP data was unavailable.
Different data sources use different categorization schemes, requiring careful interpretation.
